Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Networked Game Theory and Mechanism Design

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This CAREER project studies the theoretical properties underlying social networks. The focus of the research is two-fold: first, models are created to explain the formation and evolution of social networks. Particular emphasis is placed on the co-evolution of social networks and social behaviors such as smoking or the choice of profession. Next, these models are leveraged to help social planners build systems for networked societies that, say, maximize the spread of a particular social norm or generate large revenue from the sale of a socially-enabled product. The proposed modeling techniques combine economic theory and stochastic processes with standard graph theory in order to generate models that capture both the self-motivated interests of individuals in social networks as well as the randomness inherent in social interactions. The induced social planning problems are often computationally-intractable, so the proposed techniques also incorporate approximation algorithms and average-case analysis in an attempt to design practical and efficient systems.

The broader impact of the proposed research will be to increase awareness and understanding of the power of social networks, enabling more effective and efficient design of systems that operate in the context of social networks. Such advances can be used to create and facilitate social networking platforms by guiding the network evolution, to promote socially-beneficial behaviors such as anti-smoking norms or charitable contributions, and to help stimulate the economy by increasing revenues of socially-oriented products. The PI will also pursue several educational and outreach efforts, focusing on individuals outside standard academic institutions. The PI will reach out to high school students and working adults through popular science articles and Science Cafes. Additionally, the PI will disseminate knowledge to developing nations such as Iran, the West Bank, and Uganda through onsite summer schools in an effort to promote the science and education that are fundamental and essential for those nations' futures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project studies the structure and impact of social networks on social, economic, and information systems. 

The first investigation considered the impact of geographically-based social networks on segregation. A famous model first introduced by Schelling in 1969 posits that individuals are not overtly racist, but simply wish to avoid being a minority in their own neighborhood. Schelling argued such preferences lead to segregation even though no one actually prefers segregated societies. In our work, we study the degree of segregation induced by this model: does the society segregate on a global scale, creating entire cities of one ethnicity, or does segregation occur at a local scale, creating many co-existing ethnic neighborhoods? A formal analysis of this question stumped researchers due to the mathematical complexity of the underlying model. We adapted tools relating the discrete Schelling process to differential equations describing a continuous time process and were thereby able to rigorously analyze the process. We found that Schelling's model results in segregation, but only at a local level. 

The second investigation considered the evolution of cooperation in dynamic social networks. We wanted to understand what factors contribute to cooperation in settings, like online marketplaces, where it is easy to cheat. Economists model cooperation using the Prisoner's Dilemma game in which two prisoners must decide whether to cooperate with each other or defect on one another. Mutual cooperation is beneficial, but defecting while the partner cooperates offers the defector greater benefits at the cost of the cooperator. This mirrors situations in online marketplaces where a buyer or seller may renege on a deal after the other has committed, thereby reaping additional benefits from the trade. Despite strong incentives to defect in such situations, most communities observe a high degree of cooperation even when people are mostly anonymous (thus eliminating fear of retribution due to bad reputation). We show that high levels of cooperation are provably sustainable in equilibrium for anonymous societies when the social network co-evolves with the game play. This is because the cooperators are able to build up social capitol (in the form of a large network of game partners). The benefits of this social capitol, and the difficulty inherent in acquiring it, give incentives to continue cooperating.

The third investigation considered the dissemination of information in social networks. In our model, each individual in a network holds a private, independent opinion about a product or idea, biased toward a ground truth. This could be, for example, whether certain eating habits are healthy, whether certain investment decisions are wise, etc. In large populations, the "law of large numbers" suggests that the private opinions of individuals contain enough information for the society to discover the ground truth.  Prior research shows, however, that, as people update their beliefs based on the actions of their friends, there's a good chance that every individual in the society will end up believing the wrong thing!  'Social influence can obliterate information.  Our main result is that social networks with certain realistic structural properties avoid this pitfall and enable a population to effectively aggregate information. 

Through this project, we have learned that social networks significantly impact societal outcomes.  By chance, or perhaps by a design still not fully understood, this societal fabric mitigates negative outcomes: the structure and evolution of social networks supports low segregation, high cooperation, and effective information aggregation.
